heisig_chinese_memo: The hanzi looks like an elephant with tusks (tooth). The box is the elephant's eye. The final stroke is the tusk.
heisig_story: If you play with this primitive's form with pencil and paper, you will see that it begins with a box-like shape, and ends with the final two strokes of the halberd, a convenient combination for the tusk protruding from the mouth of an animal.
koohiiStory1: The kanji looks like an elephant with tusks. the box is the elephantÂ´s eye. The final stroke is the tusk.
koohiiStory2: He stored the tusks into a box, along with the broken halberds.
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The fang radical and the fang kanji are exactly the same! Fantastic. Oh, also it means tusk. It means fang and tusk.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Since the fang radical is the same as the fang kanji, that should be easy to remember. Tusks arenâ€™t too different from fangs, so that shouldnâ€™t be too hard to remember either.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Lots of animals have fangs, even ones that don't look like they do. The coolest fang-having animal is the gecko (ã’)! They have pretty sharp little fangs in their mouths and they'll bite you if you keep tapping their glass cages like that. Cut it out.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Picture a gecko with cute little fangs. You can keep thinking they're cute as long as one never bites you. They may be little, but gecko fangs are no joke!

humanum_full_description_en:
There are sometimes no distinctions between the positive and negative of ancient characters. The glyph of "ç‰™" is placed upright. If the glyph is rotated 90 degrees counterclockwise, the inscription is like the shape of teeth staggered up and down, the original meaning of teeth. " Tooth " is different from " tooth ". According to "Shuowen", " tooth " refers to the front teeth, and " tooth " refers to the big teeth and molars behind.

"Said Wen": "Teeth, male teeth. The shape of the elephant is in the upper and lower parts. All teeth belong to the teeth. ğ¤˜ˆ, ancient Chinese teeth." "Mao Poems. Zhao Nan. "Xing Lu": "Who is a mouse without teeth? Why do you wear me? Who is a woman homeless? Why do I have to sue me quickly? Although I sue, I will not follow."

Warring States bamboo " tooth under" word by " tooth " word signifier, is "Wen said," the classical book.

Since the character "ç‰™" is like the teeth interlaced up and down, it means interlacing and interacting, so the character " mutual " is differentiated. "ç‰™" and " mutual " are cognate characters with closely related meanings.

Bronze inscription is used as the original meaning to express the sharp teeth of beasts. Shi Kezhen: "Defend (defend) the (imperial) king's body and act as a claw." " Claw " is a metaphor for a right-hand man. See the word " claw ". Also used as a name.

The " teeth " and " the voice" of similar, so the Warring States bamboo, the " teeth " word can be under the guise of " and " because of " teeth allogeneic the" scribe change but also for " and " later " and " will be considered It is a variant of " and ". Note that the " and " in the word " and " is actually the word " tooth " (" and " and " tooth " are both official inscriptions of the inscription " tooth "), and " tooth " is eliminated from the word " and " In addition to the sound talisman, it also reflects the tradition of the ancients who donated teeth to each other to conclude a marriage contract, see " and ".

"Guodian Chu Jian. "Yu Cong III" Jane 9: "Tooth (and) travels for the righteous, and benefits. Tooth (and) the villager, benefits.... Tooth (and) is not good for scholars to travel, and members (loss).

Basic explanation of words
tooth
yÃ¡
Tooth (large teeth were called "tooth" in ancient times, and now "tooth" is a general term for teeth, also known as "teeth"): tartar. Gums. Dentition. Tooth sacrifice.
Things that look like teeth: drawer teeth.
Especially ivory: tooth carving.
In the old days, people who profited from buying and selling were introduced: dental dealers. Tooth line.

"Ya 3" was passed falsely.
(1) Refers to large teeth and molars. In ancient times, when the lips were called teeth, those behind the auxiliary vehicles were called teeth.
(2) Generic term for teeth.
(3) Bite.
(4) Said utensils shaped like teeth.
(5) Especially refers to ivory.
(6) Flag name.
(7) In ancient times, it was called the residence of the military chief.
(8) Camp; Garrison.
(9) The name of the ancient government office. Later, it is often referred to as "Ya".
(10) The ancient name for the royal court of the northwest minority nationalities.
(11) Refers to the tooth person or tooth line.
(12) Male, male.
(13) Dental plate. At first it was made of ivory, and then sandalwood was mostly used.
(14) Quantifiers. lock.
(15) See "Ya".
(16) Through "bud". Sprout; sprouted.
(17) Through "bud". Young sprouts of plants.
(18) Through "you". Child. See "yazi", "yaer".
(19) Last name. See "TongzhiÂ·Clan IV".

Reading Mnemonic
Lots of animals have fangs, even ones that don't look like they do. The coolest fang-having animal is the gecko (ã’)! They have pretty sharp little fangs in their mouths and they'll bite you if you keep tapping their glass cages like that. Cut it out.
